_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Blundell Geothermal Power Plant (hereafter referred to as Blundell) is owned and operated by PacifiCorp.  Blundell is located near the city of Milford, Utah within the Roosevelt Hot Springs Geothermal Area.  The North American Industrial Classification System code for the facility is 221116, Other Electrical Power Generation.  PacifiCorp operates Blundell in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and health and safety regulations and is committed to maintaining compliance with these regulations.  Blundell has implemented emergency response procedures at the facility in coordination with local emergency response agencies. 



Blundell consists of two independent geothermal power plants and associated geothermal wells.  The existing power plant referred to as Unit 1 is a single-flash steam generated power plant.  As a single-flash power plant, Unit 1 uses geothermal steam as the motive fluid for power generation and therefore, is not subject to the U.S. Environmental Protections Agency's Risk Management Plan requirements (RMP) for Chemical Accident Prevention or the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  The Integrated Two Level Unit Ormat Energy Converter (ITLU OEC) referred to as Unit 2, is a binary process that utilizes isopentane as the motive fluid for power generation.  The amount of isopentane in the process exceeds 10,000 pounds, which is the threshold quantity for isopentane as stated in the RMP and PSM regulations, therefore, the RMP/PSM programs apply to this process.



The RMP/PSM regulations require proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur because of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment.  The RMP/PSM regulations define the responsibilities of employers and contractors involved in work that affects or takes place near processes covered by the regulations to ensure the safety of both plant

and contractor employees and the potential effects on public and environmental receptors (RMP only).  This document describes the procedures, training, engineering controls and emergency response programs implemented by Blundell to prevent or minimize the release of hazardous chemicals from its covered process. 



The primary chemical used at Blundell Unit 2 is isopentane.  In the binary process of electrical generation, isopentane is used as the motive fluid in the generation of electricity.  Geothermal fluid is used to heat isopentane liquid to vapor in the ITLU OEC, which in turn is used as the motive fluid to drive turbines connected to a generator to produce electricity.  The isopentane vapor is then condensed and reused in a continuous, closed-loop process within each ITLU OEC.  This process does not involve any chemical reactions or changes to the isopentane. 



It is the policy of Blundell that the receipt, storage and handling of isopentane at its facility be done in a manner that meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases of isopentane into the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public and the environment.  In order to accomplish this goal, Blundell has performed the following tasks:



?    Gathered safety information on the process, equipment and procedures involving isopentane

?    Performed a structured Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and evaluated external events that might affect the process 

?    Performed an off-site consequences analysis of defined release scenarios 

?    Established a written program for prevention and mitigation of accidental releases 

?    Established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.



An integral part of the RMP/PSM program is the completion of a PHA of the facility's storage and use of isopentane in the ITLU OEC.  The PHA was conducted using a hazards and operability (HAZOP) study.  A team compos

ed of Blundell personnel with detailed knowledge of the process were directed through the HAZOP study by a facilitator.  The objective of the study was to identify potential deviations from normal operating parameters of the process, causes for these deviations, potential consequences associated with these deviations and appropriate responses or actions to mitigate the identified hazards.  A relative risk ranking based on the probability and severity of the hazards was used to assign a hazard category to each identified deviation.  A What If? analysis, human factors evaluation and facility siting evaluation were also performed as part of the PHA to evaluate other circumstances or outside influences beyond the control of the system operators and maintenance personnel.  The PHA/HAZOP study team evaluated these influences and their possible consequences were discussed.  For each consequence, a mitigating action was presented and/or developed to address such occurrences.  Details of the PHA can be found in a detailed report located in Appendix D.



All of the recommendations identified during the most recent PHA are listed in Appendix E.  Other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, internal or external audit activities, or other means will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.
